This is a rather thin bodied beer that reminds me of what a regular milk stout would be, but at 8% the alcohol is surprisingly detected in both taste and warmth.  Overall, this is a really good but not great offering.

22oz bomber courtesy of lushawn. thanks, shawn! pours black with a thick, creamy, dark beige head and very nice lacing. aroma is very nice, i definitely get the "Baltic" part, with notes of milk chocolate, lactose, and sweet, dark fruit notes with hints of licorice, fresh rubber, and light, orange peel notes. flavor is very tasty as well with creamy, sweet lactose sugar and milk chocolate up front backed by dry, herbal hops, caramel malts, and candied nuts with hints of licorice candy, red fruits, and light ash. palate is medium bodied and creamy with mild carbonation and a lightly roasted finish. overall, a tasty sweet stout.
UPDATED: APR 22, 2013 65cl, as Moloko Milk Stout, exclusive American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex Stout, yet easy to drink, balanced, hazy, good head, good brew, yet expensive!

Bottle from Keg Liquors.  Dark deep brown-black pour with a thin brown head.  Not much head retention with this.  The aroma shows oats, light ash, milk chocolate, and coffee with a good dose of half and half.  The flavor adds a little dark fruit to the milk chocolate and coffee.  This is slick and creamy.  Definitely has a cream and milky feel to it.  Almost tastes like theres a splash of Baileys or something like that in there.  The sweetness of the beer is balanced pretty well by some roasty bitterness but its still a bit on the sweet side for my liking.  Overall this is a pretty good Sweet Stout but something I probably wont seek out again
Pours black with a creamy tan head.  The aroma is of roasted malts, coffee, and brown sugar.  The flavor is rather sweet with coffee notes and licorice.
dark black pour.little head. noe is different, boozy sweet and a touch funky. flavor is similar all good baltic poter flavors with a touch of sour but still nice.

The aroma is sweet and a bit malty and warming. The color is poured. Out darkbrown amber with a small cappucinno head. The flavor of a creamy smooth milk stout with a pleasing thick but palatable body.

10/23/10.  Bomber.  Solid black pour with a small brown head.  Slightly sour and sweet aroma with hints of coffee.  The flavor is more pronounced with big sweet, sour stout and cherries, chocolate, and roasted coffee.  Pretty nice!
On tap at fff. Another treat as this is a limited release. Not my style but enjoyed it nonenthe less
Draft at Craftheads (Tokyo). Plenty of roasted coffee on the nose. Complex - milk chocolate at first, then more coffee comes through. A bit mocha-like. Easy drinking for 8%.

Poured a black color with a rather thin head. Aroma has a fair bit of chocolate and some toffee. Taste is quite heavy on the sweet lactose, reminiscent of a coffee creamer. Body is quite medium-light. Maybe Im just biased against the style but there just isnt anything that unique or interesting about this beer. Good for the style though.

22 oz bottle. Black with a very small brown head. Aroma was coffee, sweet malt, and a hint of dark fruit. Very sweet flavor, milky chocolate, and a slightly smoky bitterness. Something elusive.. maybe vanilla? Medium bodied with a little carbonated tingle. Very tasty dessert beer.

75cl bottle from a friend.
Off white head. Very dark. A great milk stout.  Subtle aroma.
22 ounce bomber-black brown pour -brown head -aroma and taste of cream,chocolate,coffee,some dark licorice-has a choco malty creamy smooth finish

Pours a very dark brown, almost black. Nose is like a sweet iced mocha, taste is great, sweetness is just hinted, nice roasty coffee flavor, booze is very well hidden, but has a hint of warming capabilities on the finish. quite a unique and tasty beer.

(bottle - 22 oz) Dark black with a thick and fluffy tan head. Incredibly roasty aroma with a nice coffee and cocoa followup. Very sweet and milky at the start of the flavor. A lot sweeter than I thought it would be from the aroma. Creamy and smooth with a chocolate milkshake finish. Awesome.

Appearance:  Pours a dark brown with barley any head.

Aroma: Milk chocolate.

Taste: Dark chocolate, licorice, milk chocolate, roast.

Mouthfeel:   Full, rather carbonated.

Overall:  Solid. Not overly complex, but very drinkable.

Pours black. Small beige head. Aroma mostly of dark chocolate, with only hints of lactose sugar. Toasty finish. Flavor is definately milky, big lactose, cocoa, roasted malt, and quaker oatmeal. Creamy mouthfeel.

Pours dark chocolate color with minimal head.  Aroma of caramel and chocolate.  Bittersweet chocolate taste that fades into a light sweet taste.  Medium body with a creamy texture.  This is a great beer!  At 8% the alcohol is hidden well.

22oz bomber.  Opaque black with a rusty beige head.  Mellow, malty chocolate milk aroma, lots of cocoa.  Rich and sugary sweet, there is also a rich, fruity undercurrent in the Baltic Porter or Caribbean Stout style.  Thick chocolate tones, luscious.  Really nails the style, though there is considerably more specialty malt sugariness than in any "traditional" version.  A world class beer all the way.  Big, full body,but very subdued alcohol.  Unique and quite excellent.

22oz bottle. Ive had this one before, but its been quite a while; from what I remember, its very delicious, so I got it again. Pours a pitch black color with a tiny tan head that dies very quickly. Smells of a light sweetness with bits of coffee and chocolate thrown in. A great taste, with lots of roasted chocolate and coffee, with a sweetness and lightness to it that makes it a true milk stout. Unlike other milk stout though, it still packs a powerful taste. A very impressive milk stout, and another home run by Three Floyds.

Pours super dark. Light cannot penetrate its stoutness.
Thin toasty head, brownish tan.
Toasty caramel aroma with chocolate smells.
Very smooth and soft on the tongue. Velvety with light carbonation.
Chocolate milk beer. Lots of chocolate flavor with a little coffe. Some milky aftertaste with some bitterness that catches up near the end.
Neae the bottom of this beer, I started to notice the alcohol taste much more, especially in the nose.
A good beer that I could have 3 of.
Black pour. Thin head. Sweet roasted/coffee. Sweet flavor. Slight bitter finish. Light in the coffee which I like as Im not a coffee drinker. Balanced. Very good b
Thick black pour, thin tan head.  Medium body, hops, and carbonation.  Smooth finish of malts and cream.

This is one for those who enjoy sweeter beers for sure. It pours black w/ a tan head. It is not sticky sweet like many big, barleywine-ish imperial stouts but rather smooth and chocolaty sweet w/ a creaminess that implies a bit of vanilla. This is all about the dark grains and velvety texture. It serves as a very nice dessert beer.

22 oz bottle pours thick and heavy almost black with brown head. Mild, sweet aroma of roasted malt and chocolate.  Nice body not as heavy as some.  Flavor is unique very sweet then roasted malt/chocolate with some burnt and bitter at the finish. And of course the warming sensation of all good stouts.   Another great brew from 3F.

22 oz bomber not much aroma but a very decent stout pour with a tan head on a dark brown body. Very sweet taste as the name implies and very nice after taste on the palate. Heavy on the malts and light on the hops. the 8%ABV is hidden with the sweet malts. Lots of flavor bit of resin taste, chocolate, yes and of course a hint of milk. Im a fan of 3 floyds and like their work.

A: pours a pitch black color. nice light brown head, moderate retention level. faint amount of lacing.

S: deep rich chocolate aromas, sweet malts, with some lactos in the nose. some coffee and toffee notes.

T: slightly smokey, with a huge chocolate tone. big coffee and toffee flavors. light hops but they are present, slightly. huge malts in this one. great flavors for the style.

M: extremely creamy. smooth and mellow for the ABV. medium to light bodied for the style and ABV. very mellow carbonation level.

D: wow. that should sum it up. I do prefer other milk/sweet stouts, but this is up there for me. great flavors, wonderful aroma and a very relaxing when it comes to drinkability.

Deep dark brown pour with some foamy tan head - minimal retention and lacing.

Sweet malty aroma.  Flavor is sweet, but not overly so.  Chocolate and milky smooth with a nice sweet malty finish.  Medium bodied, but still nice and chewy,   Delicious beer - easily the best milk stout Ive ever had.  I can drink this anytime.  Superb!

YUM!

2oz bomber, courtesy fantomas23. Pours a dark chocolate brown color topped by a small, foamy tan colored head that settles quickly to a thin film. Some spots of lacing dot the glass. The aroma shows notes of dark chocolate, vanilla, burnt caramel, and tons of creamy lactose. The flavors follows suit with the smooth dark chocolate and vanilla up front to go with some creamy lactose. Full bodied and creamy on the mouthfeel with balanced carbonation and a slightly dry, chalky finish. Definitely the most lactose Ive had in a stout. Overall a really nice milk stout.

Brand New 2010 Bottle: Pours a dark brown/black, with a big and longlasting tan head. Smells of Roasted and oats and chocolate, with flavors of Roasted oats, malted milk, chocolate- Some Sweetness and Bitterness. A medium , thick texture - Another great FFFs brew.

22 ounce bottle, I guess its about a year old since I think this brew is usually released sometime in August.  Served in a pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with a half inch brown head.  Head retention and lacing are both good.  Aroma is roasted malt, milk chocolate, coffee, and some cream.  The aroma is very sweet.  The taste is pretty sweet too, the beer tastes like milk chocolate, lactose, roasted malt, molasses, vanilla, and a bit of caramel.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit coating with moderate carbonation.  Drinkability is pretty good, its smooth and very easy to drink.  I think this is a very good brew, the age sure hasnt hurt it at all.  Id definitely buy this again the next time I find it.

Bottle. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a sweetish roasted malty chocolate aroma. Sweetish malty milk chocolate flavor with some roasted hints. Has a sweetish malty chocolate finish.

22 oz. bottle from City-Wide Liquors, picked up by shawnm213 for me.  Thanks again, Shawn!  This label is one of the most awesome beer labels Ive ever seen, but then again Im a huge fan of both the book and movie A Clockwork Orange.  Pours a cloudy dark brown with a minimal beige head.  Aroma of roasted malts, sugar, cream, raisins, caramel, and cola.  Flavor of roasted malts, cream, raisins, tart cherries, milk sugar, toast, nuts, and cocoa powder.  Medium-bodied, with a mouth-coating sugary milk powder thing going on and mild carbonation.  This is exactly what a milk stout should be.

Bottle courtesy of StFun that I took to the Shenandoah Throwdown.  Pours a mostly clear brown with a medium sized beige head.  Sweet chocolate and caramel, nice roast.  Medium bodied, full of chocolate pudding.  Faint tartness, big lactose sweetness.  Nice

22oz bomber.Pours a murky dark brown-black with pillowy tan head that quickly vanishes without leaving so much as a foam ring. Aroma is nothing too special, some roasty malt grain and a touch of raisin, maybe a hint of molasses. Flavor is much stronger than the aroma lets on, with a dried dark cherry lead-in thats followed by milk sweetness with a touch of that sour flavor that comes on when milk gets warm. Then the crunchy toasted grain comes and washes it all away, leaving a thick coating on the palate on its way to leaving a grainy-dry and gently milk-sour aftertaste. I was skeptical at first but a couple sips made me a believer.
Bottle from Jon.  Big coffee lactose aromas.  Black with on inch of beige head, and it is lacey.  The taste is very lactose, chocolate and then milk finishes. Creamy mouthfeel.

Bottle tasting at DLD. Youll have to forgive me for my less than thourough tasting notes... a drunk taster with a destroyed palate does not, a proficient rater, make!
"A very well done lactose stout, sweet but balanced." <--- Official tasting notes.
I really liked this milk stout.  Shared this all around with a number of other people and it was generally accepted as one of the best lactose sugar beers we have had.  I cant wait for this to come back out in August, Ill be all over it.

opaque black, dense brown head, creamy full body, med-co2.

aroma: lots of sweet chocolate malt, roasty, slightly leafy.

taste: roasted chocolate malt, co2 T1; very milk chocolate T2; leafy, milk T3.

doesnt have that unpleasant flavor i associate with lactose. oats really enhance the chocolate malts and the body/texture. very enjoyable and easy-drinking throughout.

a very nice milk stout. aroma and flavor are chocolate milk and some coffee mixed in. pours black with a tan head and descent lacing. has a nice creamy mouthfeel to it, and is sweet and a little sticky. very nice.

22oz bottle. Poured an opaque black color. The head was fluffy and light brown with an orange tint. It reduced relatively quickly (less than a minute) to a thin lasting film. I think the aroma is well described as a dark chocolate milk shake made with sweet cream. Rich. Luxurious. There were also delicate whiffs of anise and coffee. Medium to full boded and sweet. Carbonation was on the lower end of the spectrum with a resulting smooth, creamy mouth feel. The flavors followed the aroma elements to a T with chocolate up front accompanied by caramel and sweet cream. A splash of anise emerged at the end. Not your typical strong stout.
Dark brown, tan head, rich and tasty, Bombers are the only way to go, Drank in Blue Heaven

Dark brown with a thin tan head, slowly diminishing.  Aroma of sweet, dark and roasted malts, coffee and a hint of chocolate.  Taste is moderately sweet with chocolate, milk sugar, dark and roasted malts and mild caramel.  Pretty solid milk stout.

..bottle bought to Freetail for the ORB release.. Pours out a medium brown .. good lacing.. aged 2 years and its mellowed alot! ..very subtle..a decent and high end milky.. . The Korova milkbar sold milk-plus, milk plus vellocet or synthemesc or drencrom, which is what we were drinking. This would sharpen you up and make you ready for a bit of the old ultra violence ..

Bottle.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts.  Notes of burnt malts, lactose, and sweet malts come out.  Palate is smooth.  Flavor is strong with coffee, but the a chocolate milk flavor comes out in. The finish.  Pretty impressive.

22oz courtesy of tjthresh shared with SpencerDB. Pours nearly jet black with a thin tan head that has fairly good retention and lacing. Aroma is at first a bit funky and metallic and then as it warms turns to muted tobacco, coffee, roasted malt. Taste is very sweet chocolate, oily ganache, brown sugar oatmeal. Sweet but not cloying. Huge oily mouthfeel. 8% is well hidden. So easy to drink from the oats in the mash it could be a session stout.

Pours a deep black color with small brown highlights and a thin light brown head. Strong aroma of vanilla and fruits. The flavor also has vanilla and fruits, but its dominated by an unbearable sweetness that doesnt make me feel like having another sip.

A: The pour is a deep, dark brown color (almost black) with a modest tan head.

S: This is a fairly roast and coffee forward beer with some background notes of chocolate, cream, and a slight sweetness.

T: The sweetness was nowhere near as pronounced in the flavor as Im accustomed to with milk stouts. That said, there were still some nice coffee, roasted malt, and mild cream flavors.

M: The body is medium with a a fairly conservative level of carbonation.

D: While not as sweet as many other examples of the style, I enjoyed the roasted and coffee notes this beer provided. The more milk stouts I drink, the more I enjoy them.
22oz - Aroma of roasted malts,  lacto, chocolate and a touch of hops.  Flavor matches.  Palate is sweet and clean.  Tasty and drinkable.

Courtesy of KimBlack color; creamy head. Nice chocolate aroma, milky, with some cocoa powder. Good body, chocolate and caramel flavor, the milk and creamy presence is even clearer. Balanced, peculiar. Pleasant.

22 oz. bottle courtesy of tjthresh as part of NP10V4.  Pours black with a moderate, luscious and bubbly brown head that lasted through two-thirds of the glass and left nearly complete lace.  Very pleasant aroma of lightly roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and toffee.  As much as I enjoyed the aroma, the flavor is even better with ample chocolate, lightly roasted malt, mild coffee, milk, and coconut.  Sweet, but in no way cloying.  Medium-full bodied.  Well rounded and creamy on the palate.  Simply put, this is one of the best milk stouts I have come across.
Light aroma of sour milk and dark roasted malts.  Flavor is well balanced but not particularly distinctive with a light sweetness.

Bottle 22fl.oz.Clear dark brown color with a small to average, frothy - fizzy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is light heavy malty, chocolate, cacao, coconut. Flavor is light heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20100111]

Bomber.  This is definitely not my favorite style, but this was definitely tasty.  The creamy consistency is always a little odd for me, but the flavors worked well.  Aroma was pretty muted, but there was a nice chocolate and coffee flavor profile that kept me interested.

Aroma of roasted malt mixed in a glass of Bosco Chocolate milk,not as round and bold as I hoped #Fs would do it, taste that brownie batter sweet chocolate jumps out at you,very stange yet enjoyable, that lactose chocolate flavor lingers in your mouth,bitterness weaves all through,medium body not ver hopped,the 8% not noticable,an odd artificial sweetner aftertaste in finish,not as ballsy as you would expect from 3F, subtleness doesnt befit them

Near black with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with hard roasted malt, dark chocolate and espresso and milk chocolate. Flavour had dark chocolate, espresso and milk chocolate. Finished sweet. Nice and distinqtive.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a lazing dark brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt and some soy sauce. The flavor is sweet with notes of soy soy sauce, roasted malt, and some wood, leading to a dry finish.

Bottle 65 cl. Courtesy of KimJohansen. Pours an opaque black with a small beige head. Very sweet hard roasted malts with lots of vanilla and licorice - do I detect a woody, oaky edge as well. Medium body, low in carbonation, sweet hard roasted malts, vanilla and licorice. Rather subdued bitterness. Pleasant one. 110110

22 fl oz bottle, courtesy of KimJohansen. Pours dark brown to black with a fully gone head. Aroma is dark malty and hardroasted. Sweet malty, hardroasted, light smoked to ashtray-ish. Bitter and dry to acidic roasted. Dark malty along with a note of chocolate into the far finish.

bottle poured a super dark brown that appears black with a thin layer of head that fell immediately. aroma has roasted malt, chocolate, lactic sweetness, and a bit of hazelnut. mouth feel is light and silky and the carbonation on the low side. flavor has a nice roasted malt base, milk chocolate, mild coffee, tons of lactic, and light bitterness. there is a ton of milkiness but it seems light on the texture. nice flavors and a good example of style.

Bottle 22oz. - Poured dark chocolate color with small tan head.
Aroma - Chocolate chip cookie dough, brown sugar and vanilla.
Flavor - Sweet chocolate, brown sugar, Roasted malt and mild resin hop finish
Palate - medium/full bodied with creamy texture. Carbonation is average and finish is bitter and fairly short. Has milky flavored aftertaste.
Overall - Wow..great tasting stout, I liked that sweet brown sugar chocolate mixture and bitter milky finish!!

22oz bottle sampled at the DC Local tasting.  Pours a light absorbing, opaque black with a ringing tan head.  Aroma is toasted breads, nuts, coffee.  Flavor of brown sugar, chocolate, sweet cookie dough.  Finishes really thick thanks to the lacto.
Bottled. Black pour, fast-fading tan head. Malty, coffee nose. flavor was sweet malt, coffee, smoke, milk sugar, roasty, malted milk balls. Round, soft mouthfeel.

22oz bottle, thanks CaptainCougar.  Small brown body atop black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, milk chocolate, some grapefruit/earthy, light berry.  Taste is moderately sweet, bittersweet/milk chocolate, some caramel, light grapefruit,  Medium body, low carbonation.

A: A beautiful nitro pour. Tons of bubbles that built a head that any brewer would be proud of. Once settled down its dark as night with a nice 2 finger espresso head that lasts and lasts. Lacing, yeah there is lacing. Sheet after sheet from top to bottom of the glass.

S: Nice malty sweetness. Milk chocolate, coffee, and a bit of vanilla. What a stout.

T: Wow wonderful milk stout.  Starts with a nice malty chocolate taste. Milk chocolate baby. This is overtaken by coffee, and a hit of sweetened toffee. Finishes with a hint of bitterness which reminds me of espresso... Knowing this is a 3 Floyds brew you know this is hops coming out.

M: Soooo creamy. Man this is stout heaven.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2010 Bottle at home ... black .... thick short lived tan head down to tan lacing ... soft milk suger roast chocolate nose ... good body ... light bitterness ... soft roast ... again quite a lot of chocolate ... soft gentle ... very pleasant... little nutty in finsish 3.9... musa ... deep black ... sweet milky roast malt ... huge chocolate ... little coffee .. soft carbonation ... crackin ... goes very well with tye puding it was paired with 4.1

First off, amazing name taken from one of my favorite motion pictures. As for the beer, I acquired it via a trade where I got a whole ton of 3F goodies. Poured black as ink with a milk chocolate colored thick head. Aroma of milk chocolate, roasted malt and light caramel. Flavor and mouthfeel very smooth with chocolate, roast and milkiness. Another very enjoyable brew from Three Floyds.

Bottle courtesy photomike. Pours deep coffee brown with a thin tan head. Chocolatey and fruity aroma, maybe cherries and also a certain nuttiness. Flavor is similar with chocolate, light roast, a little acidity, marshmallows, milk. Mouthfeel is a little too milky and weird, body is a little thin for the abv. Messy, incohesive, but not offensive.

BOTTLE: thick oily black pour, minimal brown head. Nose is fairly mild - chocolate, mild lactose/sweetness, subtle roast. Nice thick mouthfeel. Taste is milk chocolate, again subtle roast, very easy drinking, alcohol is very hidden. Awesome beer!

22 oz. bottle via trade with StFun - Pours a dark brown color with a huge 3 finger thick dark tan head.  Hell, I only poured about 5 oz. of beer in the glass.  Some serious carbonation.  Very little lacing.  Aroma is roasted malt and dark esters.  Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, and cola.  Finish is smooth and somewhat bitter.  Medium body.  A good beer.  Thanks Josh.

Poured from 22 oz.  Darker brown with minimal tan head.  Nose of dried fruit and chocolate milk, a bit of malt. Taste was same with a hint of bitterness, medium body.  Smooth and nice with good mouthfeel. Preceded Black Sun in a tasting.

22oz bottle shared by photomike.   Black with a medium-small tan head.   Fruity aroma with light banana and some sweet chocolate.   Sweet flavor with some syrupy chocolate and light bitterness.   Syrupy, medium body with lower carbonation.   Not very interesting, coming from FFF at least.   lactose in a stout this big just doesnt seem to do much and adds an odd sweetness that doesnt really let the malt gain much definition.   Subtract the hop flavor that they like to put in al their dark beers, and this was just meh.

Thanks to whomever it was in the STL group that shared this one.  Pours very dark with a deep tan head.  The aroma has milk, milk chocolate, smooth roasted malt and sweetness.  Medium light body thats very smooth and has light carbonation.  The flavor starts with sweetness, milk chocolate, lactic acid and very smooth roastiness.  The finish gets sweeter, but it is smooth and not cloying.  Very nice easy drinking stout.
Well balanced.  Nice roasted coffee notes and slight chocolate tastes.  Some leftover sweetness but not cloying.  Very smooth and satisfying.

Bottle [22oz] shared with the gang at WaterlooWeekend Oct.09 -- c/o J&K. Pours a very deep ruby, almost black, with a spare tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, milk, chocolate, light green hops and some nuts. Flavour is delicious: Milky, chocolaty and roasty along with nuts and light hops. Alcohol is totally hidden. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel. An awesome Stout, extremely well done.

Pours brown with a brown head. It has an aroma of dark chocolate and coffee with a touch of lactose and molasses. The flavor is fruity and chocolaty with a licorice like effect on the palate. A tad acidic late with a roasted finish. Medium bodied.

[2540-20091024] Bottle. Mild milk water aroma. Brown black body with quick brown bubbles. Smooth and lightly roatsed malt flavour has a sweet finish. Full body. Nice, drinkable, good alcoholic balance.
(w/ blankboy, GregClow, HogTownHarry, jerc, tupalev)

65 cl bottle on October 30, 2009Very dark red to black color, small dark brown head. Bitter, cocoa, milk chocolate, bitter scent. Salty, milk chocolate, paper, coffee, cocoa taste. Coffee aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, low bitterness.

2009-10-24. Black body with a  small khaki head that fades. 3+ Aroma is pleasant, light roast, dark malt is milder than expected. 7+ Flavour is similarly much less assertive than I anticipated but rich. Decent malt character, lactose? - in a good way - very light bitterness in the finish. 8+ Alcohol is not at all noticeable. Smooth average to medium bodied palate. 3+ Pretty solid stout, very drinkable. Bottle from Liquor Stop, Indiana

Aroma is sweet milk chocolate and coffee.
Taste is sweet chocolate and milk.
Go figure...
Some dull cocoa is also present.
Finish is slick and sweet, but not cloying. 
Has a certain Three Floyds Je Ne Sais Quois.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2009 (bottle ( 22oz ).  shared by jerc & mabel  at October 2009 WaterlooWeekend.  Thick, slick, black-looking pour, small brown head.  Lovely creamy, mildly lactic aroma, hint of hint and rich chocolate - smooth.  Taste - wow - so smooth, HOW is this 8%?  Tastes like 4 ....  cream, Belgian chocolate, light mint/herbal bittering, mostly chocolate and light mocha - terrific.  Smooth, creamy, lightly carbonated - silky and balanced and so, so good.

22oz bottle.  Pours black with mocha brown head.  The aroma is somewhat roasty with a good amount of sweetness and a touch of raisin and date notes.  Taste is a mix of cream and roast.  Very some smooth and creaminess mouth feel, but not a overly thick.  Very nice drinkable beer.

Bomber shared by largadeer on BA - thanks, Chris!  Pours pitch black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is great with rich milk chocolate, coffee, and vanilla.  Flavor is full, sweet and well-balanced with chocolate brownies, coffee, roasted malt, and cream.  Body is medium and palate is extremely smooth.  Surprise surprise, another great beer from FFF.

Tasted 10/8/09.  22oz bomber.  Pitch with an opaque hue.  Thick dense tan head.  Aromas of chocolate and fudge.  Sweet breads and cocoa.  Medium to full bodied with a very sweet initial malt note.  Flavors of cocoa, chocolate and fudge.  Very sweet and smooth.  Silky.  Mildly tangy with a trace amount of hops.  Very well crafted sweet stout!
Dont remember this beer very much from last night...kind of a blur...some chocolate, some vanilla, and a very creamy mouthfeel. What I remember is a good beer.

650ml bottle.  Moloko pours a deep black with a small deep brown head that quickly fades.  This one is dominated by sweet chocolate and high carbonation with some licorice notes on the back end.  The 8% ABV is well hidden.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head and aromas of earthy chocolate and cream. Flavor is very chocolate based with a creamy mouthfeel and a very slight earthiness.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Creamy, full-bodied stout dominated by milk chocolate, and roasted malt. Smooth finish. Very enjoyable - as were all of the beers I had @ Three Floyds.

Bottle thanks to msante79Dense black, thin tan head that goes quickly. Heavy lactic nose, chocolate, and roasted malt, also some light spice. Flavor of roasted malt, licorice, light milk chocolate. Thin and sugary with a strong roast finish. Nothing outstanding, but easily drinkable by FFFs standards.
Bottle. Dark pour between Guinness and cola looking. Dark malts, chocolate, maybe some vanilla. Decent stout glad to try it.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2010 Solid black with a short-lived bubbly  milky brown head. Aroma is milk chocolate and black roasted malt. Does feel thick like milk in the mouth with a good balance of rich roast and sweet milk chocolate. Nice thick body with smooth carbonation.
Pours a dark black with nice beige head.  Aroma of roasted malt, milk chocolate, slight hops and coffee.  Similar taste, very sweet and chocolaty with a nice backbone of malts and hops.

Pours a lasting ring of beige head with a dark brown body.  Aromas of coffee, some cocoa, roasted malt.  Mainly the body is awesome, nice and silky.  Sweet, cocoa, roasted flavor.  Sweet, creamy finish.

Bottle shared with the barrios, scottyp, curly.  Thanks to illinismitty for picking this up for us.  Great deep black pour but with no real traces of a ring of brown head.  Nose is  roasty and mildly sweet and hints of alcohol. Flavor is much sweeter than the flavor, but still has a nice cocoa roastiness.  One of the best milk stouts Ive come across.  Awesome clockwork orange reference.

bottle - Pours black with a very minimal tan head.  It smells of roast malt, chocolate, and coffee.  The flavor is sweet with roast malt, chocolate, and lactose.  Its creamy and full bodied, going down easy and lingering pleasantly.  Good stuff.

22oz bottle thanks to pantanap. Pours a dark and opaque brown color with a thick beige head. Looks a bit like a cup of ice coffee. The aroma is sweet traditional sweet stout elements; chocolates, milk, but a light and spicy hop not lingers as well. The flavor is very nice; slightly smoky, earthy, milky, lots of sweet chocolates. A noticeable hop component and some bitterness. Very tasty and quite quaffable. Nice.

@Tampa Wkly Gathering courtesy HOPSHUNTER-22oz bottle-pours a disappearing brown head and black color.  Aroma is rich dark malt, secondary earthy/sharp hops.  Taste is rich dark malt, secondary earthy/sharp hops.

Bottle courtesy of HOPSHUNTER. POurs black, no head. Nose is coffee, cocoa, lactose sweetness and roasted barley. Flavor is smooth roasted malt, sweet toffee, some bitter hops and bakers chocolate. Nice! Nice full body, creamy, awesome!

Bottle, courtesy of cexshun.  A black beer with a small, creamy, beige head.  Nose is great, notes of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, molasses, and a touch of vanilla.  Full bodied with a creamy, milky mouth feel as well as an ample amount of carbonation.  Very milky, flavor is sweet roasted malt and coffee with slight hints of chocolate and fruity hops.  Damn I love FFF and this beer does not disapoint.  Yum!

bottle courtesy of msante79, thank you! pour is dense black with a medium sized medium brown head and some light pumpernickel ion there too. aroma is nice, especially for a sweet stout, with lots of raisins and thick syrupy notes on the nose.  taste is nice and roasty, creamy, dark, like a cup of coffee with some whipping cream in it. palate is nice and velvety, smoothon the tongue, nice carbonation. a lil too burnt and dry in the back for me, even though it is a sweet stout and it does cut the sweetness up front nicely. 

and of course, gotta love the concept, name, bottle art, etc. if you drink this and get into that mood, well this is a great beer, hence the overall. im enjoying it quite a bit myself.

Tap at the Map Room.  Deep black pour with a thick brown head.  The nose is lovely.  Sticky and rich and cocoaish with a lot of herbal roastiness.  Very silken/velvety palate.  Rich and thick with a  nice herbal sweetness.  Light black pepper through the middle along with the thick dark malts.  Toasted/chocolatey finish with a farily assertive hoppiness.  Chewy, thick and delicious.
pours a deep brown with a tan head.  Notes of bitter coffee, marshmellow, roasted malts, smores.  nice compliment tot eh chocolate cake that some chick made.  Bitter coffee and smores in a glass.

22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, and some cream/lactose.  Poured black in color with a small to medium-sized, creamy, dense, brown head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Opaque.  Not sparkling.  Medium-sized lacing.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of chocolate, roasted malts, light coffee, cream, some sugar, and a tiny hint of piney hops.  Medium body.  Slightly chalky, creamy texture.  Average carbonation.  Chocolate, roasted malt, and cream finish.  Very drinkable.
A good looking black brew.  Aroma is of chocolate and faint vanilla.  It is creamy like all FFF and has a little depth and complexity.  Just not as powerful as the other FFF beers.

Bomber in trade from Josh. Black beer with light brown head (less than 1 finger). Dark roast in the nose, and incredibly smooth dark flavor with some vanilla. Finish is long and sweet without being cloying. Nice brew.

Bomber. Black body with some brown highlights in the light. Very little head, but whats there is tan. The aroma is rich and sweet with hints of roasted malts. Chocolate, cream, vanilla and lactic acid. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly sweet and moderately bitter. Medium body and creamy, velvety texture with moderate carbonation which washes very little of the sweet milk and roasty flavor away. Yet the sweet notes are kept in check with a nice, hoppy finish. Excellent sweet stout, both in balance and richness.

Bottle. Poured black with a thin light brown head. Aroma full of dark roasted notes with a vanilla undertone. Flavor began dark but sweet chocolate and a creamy flavor become present. Creamy on the mouth.

Opaque black. Aggressive pour results in wisps of tan head. Sugary aroma of tobacco, yeast and hops. Roasted character with toffee, chocolate and coffee. The sweet lactose is very upfront. Velvet mouth feel coats very well. Im not really into sweet stouts. While I love the creamier mouth feel, the sweetness doesnt quite sit well with me.
Way too much for me! But it was interesting and creamy. Chocolate dark fruit coffee, sweet and thick. too sweet and thick

Bomber from Archer Liquors. Pours quite black with a 2-finger tan head. It has a sweetish aroma of darkly toasted malt. Medum body with creamy carbonation that bites just a bit. Flavor is toasted malt with dark fruits and some chocolate. Dark fruit aspect matches the "Baltic" descriptor.  Finishes a bit burnt, slightly bitter and rather balanced by the dark fruit. Its a really flavorful stout, and not excessively sweet. Really a lot going on in this one. Highly recommended.

My first beer from the much vaunted Three Floyds!

Pours a coffee black with a thin tan head that turns into a crown with spotting.

Smells absolutely fantastic. Chocolate, oats, sweet malt, cream.

Tastes milky (not just a clever name), light chocolate malt, light sweetness in the finish. 

Mouth is med/thick with low/med carbonation. Good.

Easily my favorite of this style so far. Wish I could get FFF in this area as they live up to the hype.
Pours pitch black with a fully receding tan head. Notes of light coffee, chocolate mousse, sweet cream, caramel, and pepper. Full bodied with lively carbonation.

Pretty neat looking bottle graphics. Very dark black pour with a thick tan head and fine carbonation. Chocolate is pretty dominate in this aroma with a dark roasted coffee note hiding in there, burnt notes and an overall sweet profile. A strong chocolate flavor starts off the tasting, moves into a very unique sweet bite (lactose?), a coffee/burnt malt middle with a light caramel ending. Brew has a moderate density, is very smooth and rich with feeling. Overall a good beer and one that really hit the spot well.

Black pour with a dark tan head. Aroma of roasted malt and lactose sweetness. Nice flavor of roasted malt and sweetness from the lactose. Nice mouthfeel and low carbonation. Leaves a nice roasted malt aftertaste with a touch os sweetness. Nice lacing on the glass.

[Bottle] Pours an opaque black color with about an inch of brown head. Roasted malts, coffee and some vanilla in the nose. A sweet, lactic character is pretty strong in the taste. Some chocolate, caramel and almond as well. Creamy mouthfeel with a perfect carbonation level. This beer seemed sweet even for a sweet stout. Nevertheless, I did enjoy trying this brew.

From a trade with Erik in Indiana. This poured from the 22 oz bottle a very dark brown with a small head and very robust lacing rings considering how small the head was. Nose of chocolate and coffee, but mild with no burnt notes. Very rich and creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is mild and very pleasant. Amazingly easy to drink. Outstanding. I liked this a lot.

Perfect name - I love it, probably because I love the movie. Deep dark brown coloured brown, still clear at the bottoms, with a thinnish and fast-dying brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, lactic milk, sourness, nuts and some toffee. Full-bodied; Strong sweet buttermilk flavour with some coffee, nuts and a dose of cherries within this one. Aftertaste shows a lot of milk, coffee and some sweetness here. Overall, a good and strong beer - showing full-bodied, sour twangs and a bunch of alcoholic sweetness. I sampled this 65 cL bottle purchased from West LakeView Liquors in Chicago, Illinois on 15-December-2008, sampled at home in Washington on 15-June-2009.

Bomber wife bought me from wis trip. Sweet candy like aroma and some roast notes. Black body with chcolate mile colored head. Carbinated brew with a creamy milk texture in it. Mainly dry coco with some roast and a milk tanke aftertaste to it. Alright brew.
Bomber, thanks TearsForBeers! Pours opaque blackish brown with a thick and lacy tan head. Medium body and light carbonation. Sweet molasses and smoke aroma. Milky coffee and chocolate taste.

pours black with small tan head that sticks to the rim. aroma is burned malt, coffee, chocolate, sweet milk, and a little alcohol. drinks smooth and thin but has a good mouth feel. flavors of coffee, chocolate and malts are all present with a lingering coffee on the back of the tongue. i prefer black sun, but this is real decent.
Pours  black with brown edgea and yhin brown head aromas of roasted malts,coffee,chocolate taste is of of the same with a sweet creamy mouthfeel very well balenced

Poured an opaque brown with a brown head.  The aroma was very nice of coffee and milk chocolate.  Milky roasted malt flavor.  medium bodied.  Goes down quick.  Nice beer that was better than I had expected.

Bottle:  Pours a pitch black with a shimmering tan head.  Nose reminds very much of chocolate-laden vietnamese coffee...very sweet and lactic based.  Body has nice carbonation, perfect for the style and still retains some silkiness.  Quite sweet to start but yields to some roasty malt notes with a bit of chocolate.   Good stout.

Shared by BDR.  I usually dont like milk stouts but Three Floyds has done a great job with this one.  Black, and an exceptionally smooth, creamy palate, but still an unusually thick beer.  Roasted malt and some sugar, a little coffee, and milk, almost like a latte. What a lactose stout should be.

Bottle from trade with brewczar.  Pours motor oil black with a dark tan head.  Nose is roast, coffee, lactose, some chocolate, and some vanilla.  Flavor is vanilla, lactose, roast, cafe con leche, and a creamy sweetness.  Great milk stout, nice yellow lace, and awesome lingering roasty sweetness in the sensual assault on the palate.  Medium-full bodied sweet stout that is very enjoyable.
Pours black with a tan head. Vanilla and chocolate aroma. Tastes of roasted malt and coco, lots of lactose.

Bomber.  Poured rich, deep brown with a dark cap of yellowy-brown head.  The aroma picked up milk chocolates with sweetened-up molasses, vanilla, and mild smoke.. soft, cake-like, and entirely enticing.  The flavor was just as good with lightly-roasted milk chocolate and vanilla at the core.. mild coffee and earthy bitterness on the edges.. light smoke and the same maltage on the long finish.  Medium-bodied and a touch grainy on the palate.. balance was great, but the 22oz was gone before I knew it.  I could drink a lot!

Bottle.  Dark black pour, thin cookie colored head with a rich vanilla chocolate aroma.  Flavor was nutty, smoky and sweet cream.  I wish the flavor would have lingered a little longer, but it was quickly gone and forgotten from the palate.  Decent FFF brew, but not worth the price.

In short: An overly sweet and very messy dark beer of some kind.  No thanks.
How:  Bottles 12oz.  Sherbrooke dinner-and-beer with Montreal crew.  Consumed fresh soon after purchase
The look: Almost black body topped by a beige ring of foam
In long: A whole lot of sweetness, way too much vanilla, annoying fruit juice concentrate (grapes mainly), a coconut touch, very lactic/milky, a lot of molasses and some toffee.  An overall sensation of a failed experiment, this is not-cohesive, very messy.   I dont know what Three Floyds were aiming for with this thing.  But eh, if you are to make a beer inspired by A Clockwork Orange, may as well make it a totally fucked-up one.

Thanks to ajm for the bottle! Only the second sweet stout Ive rated. Pours a glossy black with a very thin, tan head. Thick molasses dominates the nose, with some tootsie-roll chocolate, dulce de leche (thats appropriate)... really good, creamy chocolate milk. This is interesting stuff. Really not sure what I think of it. Im so used to Impys that it seems a bit dilute, but its certainly flavorful. The mouthfeel is silky smooth, but lacks the carbonation to keep it from feeling flat. Just a bit sour... but its the odd "this is a bit off" sour, not a crisp, tart sour. I realize its just lactose sugars, but I cant get my mind off the idea that theres been milk sitting in here for months, and its sort of weirding me out. Crazy brew to try, and Ill certainly give anything from FFF a shot - but I probably wouldnt seek out this style again.

Black in colour with a thin tan head and very light lacing.  The aroma is lightly roasty, creamy, some dark chocolate and some sweetness.  The flavour is roasty, some mild chocolate, quite creamy with a moderate sweetness.  Sweet mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes long and creamy with a moderate bitterness.
The milk really makes this one really creamy.  Really enjoyable.
650ml bottle from Sahara Mart in Bloomington, Indiana.
Opened on November 16, 2008.
Bottle from 2008.

Bottle courtesy of Awiseman01. Pours a chocolaty brown with a diapering oak brown head. Noise is chocolate milk with hints of oak and coconut. Flavors are a mild dark chocolate, nice maltiness, slight oak hints, and a milk sugar taste late in the sip. Mouth is creamy with a slight dryness to the finish. One of my favorite sweet stouts.

Black-dark brown with a thin brown head. Sharp wet wood, roast pine aroma; small coffee and maybe bitter chocolate. Strong roadst meat adn wood, slight hop floral with strong bitter. again some coffee and cacao and a very this edge of sour. Continues to hold up and provides a short lived but balanced finish.

Bottle from Lone Hill shared with DuffmanSW.  Pours black with a short creamy light brown head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma is grainy and buttery with a load of chocolate milk.  Flavor is more subtle than expected.  Chocolatey and smooth, easy to drink and sweet with very little bitterness.  Unfortunately it does not get better as it warms, as it seems to sour.  Mouthfeel is silky smooth with creamy carbonation.

Bottle thanks to ilovedarkbeer. Pours with a frothy mocha head that fades over a thick black body. Aroma of cocoa powder, fudge, raisins (special b malt), vanilla, lactose and leather. Taste is sweet with tons of lactose, leather, dark chocolate bar, caramelized malt, and coffee creamer. Smooth, thick mouthfeel with light carbonation. Good beer!

Darker brown color with a sweet chocolate-milky-roasty aroma.  Flavor is roasty and sweet with lots of milk.  Chocolate is pleasant upfront, but milkiness makes me want to run and take a shit.  OK, but 3Fs has so many better porters and stouts.

Pours a deep coffee black color with a small light brown bubbly head. Nose is milk chocolate, brownie, milk, little bit of roasted malt faint raisin. Taste is chocolate (darker)   Creamy medium mouthfeel. little bit of dust, and leather. Over all pretty good. Kind of acidic too.

Bomber! Dark stout blackish brown with thin brown foamy head. Smell was good, a bit on the sweet side. Taste is average with a bit of a hoppy ending and a heavy and dry mouthfeel. Expected a better flavor from FFF, this was not over the top for a stout.
Black with a thin brown head, chocolatey aroma and flavor great you and are followed up by some bitterness and a sweet finish.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2009 Courtesy of northernbrews
Bottle : The aroma has lots of dark chocolate with moderate roast, a hint of black licorice, and faint coffee.  It pours a dark brown, virtually black, with a small tan head.  The flavor starts with lots of chocolate.  There is a hint of sour fruitiness in the background along with some black licorice.  The finish has some mild roasted coffee.  Medium-full voided with a soft and creamy mouthfeel.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a dark brown color with a small to medium beige head.  The aroma is fairly sweet, chocolate milk, fresh tobacco leaves, oats, and a touch of fruit.  The flavor has a nice roasted quality with sweet creamy chocolate, vanilla, smooth and balanced without the annoying sourness that accompanies many sweet stouts.  Very solid.

Bottle shared at the sexual chocolate gathering by stfun i think, maybe tjthresh or somebody else in the ever-so-generous indy crew. This was a nice sweet stout and one of the more balanced three floyds beers I have had. Nice and creamy with nice chocolate and mild coffee flavors.
Sweet, milk pudding like aromas.  Flavors of cappuchino, smoked malt, milk chocolate.  Medium to low thickness on the palate.  Pretty drinkable as a desert beer.

My Bottom Line:
This super-sweet Milk Stout offers loads of vanilla, milk chocolate and coconut flavors for a creamy pint of dessert not for the faint of tongue.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam tops the brown-tinged black.
-A certain fruitiness is apparent in the nose, akin to maraschino cherries.
-The light carbonation makes the sweetness overshoot its purpose and diminishes drinkability.
-The finish does offer some earthy, almost vegetal hop notes, but the prevalent sweetness tends to wash over them pretty quickly.

Bottle.

Bomber pours out a dark brown with a thin, quickly receding tan head. Lots of coffee and chocolate in the aroma, but sruprisinlgy light on the hops for a FFF brew. Very smooth, creamy medium body with very light carbonation, and a silky mouthfeel. Sweet, light molasses character with a milk chocolate character, and little in the way of bitterness. Certainly a different type of offering from FFF.

Bottle from my friend Cheryl. Pours dark brown with a huge brown head. Medium to full bodied with a creamy texture- rich and smooth but not thick. Aroma is milky and roasty. Flavor of dark chocolate, milk, and mild roasted malts, countered by a moderate hoppiness and a hint of anise. I like the amount of attenuation on this one. Finish is slightly dry and acidic. Nice beer. Bottle says Milk Stout, but perhaps a bit too hoppy for that. Thats ok, the beer works for me.
Pours out black with brown head. Taste is sweet with some hop bite. With roasted coffe and milk chocolate notes. Very drinkable, tasty stout.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Black in color with a very small beige head. aroma is of mocha, hot chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts, and marshmallow. Taste is a lot like a 3 musketeers bar with chocolate, mocha and marshmallow.

22 oz. bottle - thanks riversideak!!  light brown with thin tan head; texture is thin and it drinks smooth; kind of a cross between a porter and stout; aromas of chocolate, sweet candy, vanilla and touch of spice; very nice, but didnt jump out much to me
aroma is a bit weak, some sweetness and the slight kibble like smell. there is a sweetness with a touch of coffee and fruit. smooth around but gives some over fizz.

The aroma is good except for a touch of cat food. There is also cream, coffee, chocolate, and toasted malt. The appearance is dark brown with a small head. The flavor is like the aroma minus the cat food. The palate is average for the style. Overall its a nice tasting, quality beer.

22oz bottle shared by riversideAK.  Pours dark dark brownish black in color with a thinner looking body and a condensed off-white head.  Nose is mildly roasty with some sweeter mocha notes.  Taste is more of the same, with some smooth creaminess but not a overly thick.  Good and easy drinking.

Bottle from BeerBunker. Dark pour, almost black, thin foamy head. The aroma is somewhat roasty with a good amount of sweetness too. Dark chocolate, mocha, roast, a little soy, and a touch of lactic flavors too. Smooth and very drinkable.

Sample from my man StFun - thanks, Josh! Been eager to try this, and the beer did not disappoint. The mouthfeel wasnt quite as thick as Id like, but it was still lovely and rich. Love the play of the creamy palate and the lactic flavors, but theres a surprisingly deep hop presence to this too, and a long dark chocolate finish. Nice one!

Shared at the Sexual Chocolate gathering. Pours an inky black with a chestnut brown head. The nose is mildly grainy, chocolaty, rich, some coffee, smooth, mildly sweet. The flavor is rich, chocolate coffee, very smooth, mildly grainy. The palate is smooth and rich, very full.

Sampled at Backus Backyard Bash. Dark brown with no head. Yep, its a milk stout, 3F style. A stupid sweet chick beer, IMO. Not bad, but not for me, either. Nice velvety mouthfeel. Chocolaty and lactic, 3F yeasty, typical 3F hop profile.

650ml bottle, pitch black color, with a big fluffy tan-colored head, sweet roasted, dark, chocolate malr, fruity nose, with some sweet milky lactose, chocolatey accent, with some cocoa powder, nutty, hazelnut, mochaish, ice coffe, espresso accents, with some mild burnt raisin, date notes, and a hint of spicy liquorice in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a sweet roasted, dark, toasted, chocolate cake character, with some fruity, smooth oat cereal, mellow,creamy chocolate milk, ice cream, praline, mochaish, espresso flavors, with some chocolate chip cookie, brownie, coffe essence, burnt raisin, plum, candy pipe liquorice accents, with a hint of star anise spiciness, leading towards a sweet roasty, chocolatey milkyish, fruity finish.

This poured a dark brown to black color with a big tan head. Aroma was chocolate, hints of bourbon and vanilla. Flavor was outstandingly silky and smooth. Not oversweet stout, but certainly not the bitter finish you get from other stouts either. Possibly the smoothest of the style ive ever had. Excellent stuff.

Dark brownish/black poured from a 22oz bottle. The nose brings out a sweet, nice smell with coffee/espresso and some roast. A nice burnt sugar flavor with some vanilla, almost a creme brulle flavor. Pretty tasty beer. Thanks Nelson.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  Smell is chocolate, coffee, starbucks chocolate covered coffee beans, vanilla, and dark roasted malts.  Look is dark brown almost black with a not much head.  The taste is coffee, creamy, chocolate, and roasty.

Bottle shared.  Poured dark brown.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, lactose, light smoke.  Taste is very similar, with plenty of the lactose coming through.  Mouth is full and creamy.  Finish is smoth.  Overall, a nice stout.
Dark brown pour.  Some roasted coffee in nose along with some sugars.  Nice roasted character, creamy mouthfeel, tastes like lactose.  Definitely creamy is what I took away from it.

text: Very dark brown pour with a soft fizzy brown head. Fresh coffee in the nose. Solid roastiness up front, lots of espresso with a interesting cream sweetness underneath. Dry finish with a hint of cocoa. Pretty nice coffee stout.
(22oz. bottle)  Pours a black body with a small beige head.  Aroma of lactose, chocolate, roasted malt, wood, nuts, and smoke.  Flavor of chocolate, lactose, and roasted malt.
bottle, thanks to bu11zeye, black color with no head, smokey chocolate aroma, flavors of cashews, chocolate, roast malt and molasses
bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  black pour with a short lived khaki head.  nose of roasted malts, chocolate and milk.  great thickness with a very smooth flavor of roasted malts, chocolate and milk.

22oz bottle. Pours a deep brown almost black with a 2 finger chocolate head. Tons of fresh coffee, chocolate and toasted malts on the nose.  Flavor hels cocoa dust with the booze being well hidden.  Another great one from FFF.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06.

Poured  clear dark brown color with medium brown frothy head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Medium to heavy roasted chocolate malt, woody and tobacco aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy roasted sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate duration to long duration.

My expectations where met with a very good stout.

Bottle from Lone Hill.  Pours a dark roasted brown color with a tan head.  Smells of soy milk, and tastes of powdered cocoa, coffee, vanilla, and hazelnut.  Nice, but the soy milk makes this a little too sweet for a stout.

Bottle shared by nbutler11 at the 09er.  Thanks buddy!  I dont think this goes far enough on the milk - not as good of a sweet stout as I have had.  Decent roast, very milky chocolate, smooth finish.
I forgot who I got this from, sorry and thanks!  Dark brown pour and fluffy khaki head.  Tobacco and cream on the nose.  Creamy mouth-feel.  A real easy drinker.  Roasted malts, chocolate and cream.

Dark brown color with a moderate head of tiny tan bubbles. Malt, grain, molasses, and a touch of coffee and dark chocolate in the aromas. Smooth lightly oily feel. Seems light in flavors. As sweet mocha and a touch of roasted malt splash around. Hints of lactose and bits of blackberry. This seems to be growing on me as the linger is slightly fruity with just a touch of roasted malt and dark cocoa.

1/07/2009: Three Floyds Moloko Milk Stout has a very dark brown appearance (ruby highlights) with a tan-colored head. The aroma is very smooth and silky with suggestions of chocolate and Backwoods Cigars. The flavor is roasty with some milk chocolate, tobacco, vanilla/cream and NO LACTOSE sourness. This beer has a medium-light body and is very silky smooth. This is probably one of the best milk stouts that I have encountered. I highly recommend it. 1 pint 6 Fl. Oz. bottle shared by alexsdad06. Thanks! Rating #145 for this beer.

Bomber ready "Moloko Milk Stout," i.e. nothing about "plus."  Black almost oil pour with a tan khaki head that fades to a small ring without lacing.  Smells like a chocolate milkshake, a lot like Rogue chocolate stout, with some oats.  The flavor is the same, but so remarkably flavorful and balanced and unoffensive and soft.  Silky velvetty soft on the palate with minimal carbonation.  Overall: yet another FFF masterpiece.  So good and drinkable and balanced.

This is a first for me; this is really the first Three Floyd’s beer that I would characterize as disappointing. Mouthfeel was troubling...it seemed almost greasy or oily in my mouth, and the flavor seemed a dichotomy...like a mix of too-sweet sweetness and some nice milky creamy flavor.

It poured black with not very much off-white head. Aroma was intensely roasty and definitely predicted the sweetness that I described above in the flavor. Mouthfeel was a bit strange.

OK...I found this beer interesting, but compared to my first experiences with Gumallhead, Alpha King, and Dreadnought, which were downright eurphoric...well let’s just say it wasn’t the same.

I bought this 22oz bottle at Big Red Liquor in Bloomington, IN.

650 ml, thanks General Gao. Opaque with a small but lasting ring of bubbles. Chocolate, espresso and cream fragrances. Tastes of coffee sweetened with chocolate and tingly lactose. Roasty semi-sweet finish brings on some dark chocolate and light char. Medium-heavy body is watery, a tad too fizzy, and barely dried by the roast. This one is good, but has a bit much lactose.
22oz bottle from the brewpub.  Pours a brownish black with a minimal tan head.  Malty and sugary aroma with a tad bit of hop.  Sweet and milky flavor with some roast character.  Very good.

22oz bottle. Pours a very thick and dark black body with a very small, dark brown, fizzy head that dissipates into nothing and leaves no real lacing. Aroma is a nice combination of sweet dark and tart cherries with a mild coffee roastiness. Clearly milky and chocolatey. Some nuttiness, but the almost marshmellow-like aroma is pretty cool. It grows into a much fuller aroma as it warms. Flavor is almost like drinking a chocolate milk with a dry roast backing. Very creamy and smooth. Very milk chocolatey and blended well with the coffee taste. A hazelnut mellowness to it as well. Finishes with a little sour prune taste and lingers with a sweet, oatmeal chocolate and mild coffee aftertaste. Palate is full bodied, very creamy, and very chewy. Overall, this is a damn good sweet stout. It has a very nice oatmeal feel to it and a lot of nutty chocolate that balances real well with the mild coffee beans. I like this a lot and enjoy it more and more as it warms up. Although I love FFF for their uncharacteristically hoppy beers and crazy hop additions...I appreciate how a beer like this is so well done too. Nice job.

65cl bottle from Crown Liquors (Indianapolis, IN). Pours a dark brown to black color with a foamy tan, milk chocolate head that settles quickly. Aroma is malty and sweet with notes of heavy cream, roasted malt, ripe dark fruit, coffee, nuts, and hints of caramel sweetness. Flavor is very much the same but with a stronger bitter coffee presence. Notes of roasted malt, molasses, ripe dark fruit and toffee are present as well. Generally medium body with a sweet and bitter coffee finish. Nice sweet stout.

A seriously delicious brew, and one that gets better as the bottle warms. Not what I was expected from FFF at all. Unlike most of their offerings, this one is totally subtle. Chilled, it plays like a weak milk stout, but as it warms, it becomes much more like drinking chocolate milk. Aroma and flavor are dominated by the lactose, with notes of hops in each as well. Roasted barley, hazelnut, and coffee also make themselves known in the flavor, to varying degrees as the brew warms. Nice notes of candy sugar as well. Very nice.

Bomber pours a deep black with a medium deep bubbly tan head that left spotty lacing.  Aroma of tart cherries, roasted malt, milk chocolate, coffee, nuts, caramel and some citrus notes.  Flavor of roasted malt, lactos, coffee, caramel, cherries, lightly acidic, some orange and light hop bitterness.

A fairly solid pour into my 25cl tulip glass yields a two-finger thick, darkly browned, tan colored head that sits on top of a very black colored beer.  The darkness is complete as this beer does not pass light even when held up directly to the light.  The aroma is dominated by roasted grain character; aromas of French roast coffee beans, well toasted barley husk, blackened whole grain bread, crushed well browned (not quite burnt) crackers and some sweet, burnt caramel notes.  Though amply roast focused, the nose keeps from being overly harsh.

This is quite sweet, the lactose really comes through quite strongly; it is a simple sweetness that is a touch too strong for the rest of the beer.  Underneath the sweetness is an ample roasted malt character that provides both a touch of burnt acidity as well as a roast-grain bitterness.  There is quite a bit of toasted, browned grain character to this beer as well, with notes of browned whole grain crackers and an almost burnt bread crust note.  Concentrated, yet smooth, flavors of black coffee are found towards the finish.  The body somehow seems lighter than it really is, I think this is a product of the lactose influence somehow as this beer does have some viscosity to it.

Somehow this beer is a bit simplistic.  I expect a greater malt complexity in both the flavor and the aroma; in the case of the flavor that lactose seems to drown out a lot of notes that might otherwise be noticeable.  Not bad, but a bit bland.

Pours a deep black with a thin tannish head. Aroma is surprisingly dry with, roast, chocolate, nutty and lactose. The Flavor boasts plenty of chocolate malt, lactose and a fair amount of hops (it is 3 Floyds!). Finishes more sweet and somewhat long. Medium to full body, creamy texture.

Thanks to Beerlando for this.  Pours a thick black color with a milky chocolate pillow of a head.  Smells are extra roasted with some vanilla notes.  Taste is milky and smooth with some chocolate flavor mixed in with the roasted malt.  Good milk stout.

22oz bottle, no date from Colin.  Thanks GeneralGao!  Black with a one finger tan head, fair retention.  Roasted malts, char, and light chocolate are up front with some vanilla and oats in the background.  Flavor is much the same with some black patent turning things a bit burnt. Semi dry with bitterness peaking around a 3. Hazelnuts and/or almonds show up later on in the finish. Smooth medium body with low carbonation.  Pretty good,

text: Bomber via trade with BBB63, thanks Mike shared at Alesmith BA Old Numbskull release today, everyone like this one.  Pours black with a light brown head.  Nose is smokey and sweet.  Taste is light sweet, with a lactic touch and a good roasty malt back bone.  Great milk stout.

Courtesy dchmela.  Black pour, thin broken tan head, rousing elicits a thicker head.  Real nice lactic and nutty chocolate aroma, very fresh.  Thinnish palate, real nice smooth chocolate notes and a mild roasty finish.  Quality.

Sample at the Hopsnobbery Collective tasting on 12/10/08:Thanks to JaBier for sharing a bottle. The beer pours nearly black with dark brown around the edges. Ultra-thin dark beige head that diminishes quickly, and spotty lacing. Aroma of coffee and milk chocolate with a nice roasty undertone. Medium, creamy body with flavors of coffee and roasted malt, as well as a nice sweet chocolate presence. The finish is bittersweet chocolate with a roasted coffee aftertaste. Very good overall.
A jet black brew with a thin tan head.  Aroma of smoke and nuts.  Medium body, rich balanced flavor, very smooth.  Thumbs up!

22 oz. bottle.  Dark black pour with a small tan head.  Thin, light brown film covers the glass.  Roasted malt aroma with chocolate hints.  Thin, watery mouthfeel.  Flavor is slightly sweet.  Powdered chocolate, roasted malt, and light creamy milk.  Lightly bitter finish.  Nice beer.
22 oz bomber.  Pours a pitch black with a medium brown head.  Aroma of roasted charred malts, cocoa powder, and milk chocolate.  Taste is creamy with hints of cocoa, milk chocolate and roasted malts.

Bottle.  Poured out like motor oil, thing foam clinging to edge of glass but otherwise no head.  Aroma is charred malt with citrus hops noticeable on a rich malty backbone.  Lacked the rich creamy character I’ve enjoyed in some other "milk" stouts.  Flavor is nice, hops evident, sweet chocolate malt predominates with a deeply toasted finish.  Full bodied, almost oily with a nice lingering dry bitterness.
22oz bottle from pantanap, thanks Kan. Dark black pour with a brown head. Dark roasted malt aroma. Very smooth, light coffee flavor. A little chocolate as well. Very nice drinking stout.

text:
Very generous bonused bottle in trade with pnista.  Thanks Phil!
Pours a dark black color with a short lived tan head.  Smell is coffee and roasty malt with a very light milkiness.  Taste is roasty malt and coffee and is lightly creamy, and subtley fruity.  I thought the mouthfeel was a bit thin actually, but otherwise it’s a decent sweet stout, but not FFF’s best beer.

22 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a thin tan ring.  Nose is milk chocolate and sweet coffee with hints of marzipan.  Feels a bit thin with a soft tingle.  Taste is iced coffee with a touch of molasses.  Mild bitter citrus peel to finish.

(10/14/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in Munster. Black-colored with a light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, some chocolate and some alcohol. Sweet chocolatey flavor, roasted malt, some dark fruits and some milky notes. Medium to full body.
Bottle.  Poured a dark black with a one finger brown head.  Aroma of chocolate.  Flavor was very milky and creamy with a big chocolate finish.  Great beer.

Great pour. Lots of chocolate in the nose. I get the milk stout very strongly. Sweet lingering chocolate milk. Almost a cream taste. Very nice beer. Really good after dinner, it’s cold out, we’re hanging out

Dark, sweet, hot and then clean. Leaves your palate as if there was nothing there. Aroma is nice roastiness. First flavor is kind of sour, but quickly changes to smoky sweet. Strange strange beer. definitely has a chocolate liquer flavor to it.
Crushed with Jakebra.  Very nice.  Sweet nose, chocolate and some coffee.  More in the flavor.  Pretty creamy mouthfeel.  Id take Rogue Chocolate Stout over this any day, but its pretty damn good.

22 oz bottle

It’s been a while since I’ve tried any Three Floyds beers since they are hard to come by here in Ohio.  While on a trip to Kentucky I managed to locate this and don’t regret it at all.  This is one of the best sweet stouts that I have tried and if it were available locally might go into my regular rotation.

Aroma / Appearance - The deep sandy head decorated a black body along with beautiful strands of creamy lacing.  Hazel, black coffee, skim milk, vanilla, and a mellow hoppiness formed almost a perfect blend.

Flavor / Palate - Creamy caramel, black coffee, and plum hit the tongue on the first sip.  Next comes a taste that reminds me of Starbucks’ sea salt and caramel hot chocolate.  The milk stands out most in the transition; by the finish it is a shadow on the throat.  I wish I had another bottle - hopefully this is a regular release in the future.
Bottle from lone hill. Black with a creamy head. Milk chocolate and sugar taste with a smooth texture.

Pours a thick opaque black colour with a mahogany tint near the bottom. The head is big, tan with notes of milk, chocolate, toffee and cinnamon. Not a whole lot of carbonation, but pleasent rich flavors and nuances all throughout this brew.

Bottle shared generously by BrianK.  Pours a black abyss with a creamy white head.  Lactose, minerals and calcium,  light milk chocolate, vanilla, and a slightly off flavor of sour fruit or rust.   Best served cold.
Bottle courtesy of StFun.  Pours brown with a white head.  Smells of rich malt, chocolate, dark malt.  Tastes of chocolate, rich malt, some fruit.  Full bodied and enjoyable.

Fresh bomber.  Pours an extremely dark chocolate to mahogany brown color.  A small but dense, mocha colored head settles slowly to a thin film with a prominent edge.  Soapy, spotty lacing marks the glass.  Aromas include dark cocoa, vanilla beans, scorched caramel, and heaps of creamy lactose.  This might be the most lactic stout I’ve ever encountered.  Flavors follow suit, smooth and chocolaty, with a big vanilla influence and a strong hint of evaporated milk.  The mouthfeel is substantial and smooth, almost creamy, round up front and finishing slightly dry and yeasty.  Overall, this is a damn good beer.  It might very well be the best milk stout I’ve ever had.

650mL bottle, courtesy of RiversideAK.  Thanks, Alex!  Pours a dense, dark chocolate-brown color; medium-tan head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Solid amounts of roasted malts, milk and dark chocolate, and creamy milky cocoa notes in the aroma; nice cocoa and dry toastiness.  Medium mouthfeel: creamy, relaxed carbonation; lightly acidity dark and milk chocolate, roasted malts, and very light smoked meats at the core of things.  Really nice beer.  Lengthy finish: toasty malts, cocoa, and milk chocolate, with that presence of roasted meats still lingering.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2008 A big milkshake of a beer.  More head would do this beer well, though.  Chocolate and coffee, but also oats, plumb, and roasted malt.  Milky like no other.  Drink and enjoy unless you love light beer.

22, capped. Jet black with a sense, creamy burnt tan head. Big roasty, slightly milk-soured nose. Mildly watery body, a little less than medium. Roasty, chocolatey, slightly dairy-lactic mid-palate. Mild finish.

Black pour with a very small tan head.  Aroma had plenty of oats and chocolate.  Huge oats in the flavor,  lots of chocolate, lacto, cream, coffee, and a hint of nutinines.  Finish was awesome,  low carbonation really helped this one shine through.  Very nice!

Bottle acquired via trade with chicagodri...Paul, THANKS SO MUCH!!!  Jet black pour with a 3/4 inch mocha-colored head.  Thick and flavorful...with cocoa, malt, and lactic qualities.  Can you get a DUI after drinking a chocolate milkshake???  No...think again!!!  Aroma isn’t overly aggressive but is inviting...Godiva, roasted nuts, and subtle sweetness.  Wish this was readily available in AZ!!!

on cask at the clark st ale house, chicago.  foamy dark tan/light brown head that goes quickly.  body looks blackish.  sweet milk chocolate malt aroma,  like maltballs and molasses.  some light roasted coffee too.  silky body, sticky. flavor starts chocolatey malty sweet, then flavor goes a little dark fruity like dried organic prunes.  a bit of hop bitterness but minute compared to most 3 floyds.  mild tangy finish, mild lactic aftertaste.

Bottle... Backuss Backdoor Bash 08... This beer rocks!... Pours pitch black and sits, menacingly, in my glass. Small, creamy, well-tanned head. Decent retention. Chocolaty, roasted nut aroma. Full-bodied with a velvety/silky mouthfeel and supple carbonation. Sweet, chocolaty and very lightly acrid. Lengthy, pleasantly sweet finish. Thanks to dchmela for sharing the bottle!

Bottle courtesy Eithcubes. Thick black oily pour with a thick dark tan head. Nice roasted grain aroma with a lactose sweetness all balanced very nicely. Thick creamy chocolate malt roasted grain taste with a nice lactose balance. A very good sweet stout.

Tap at the brewpub. Aww yeah, that’s what I’m talking about. Best beer of my Chicago trip by far, and my beer of the month for October. After two days of mostly pretty good beers something finally hit a homerun and reminded me why I love chasing beer so much. This beer was defined by its milkiness, and is the first milk stout I’ve had that really shows the milk decently at all. Usually they are just very lactic and kind of gross, but this one has a perfect, sweet, creamy milkiness, like whole milk, carrying forward a lovely chocolately stout flavor. Very rich but also very balanced, and perfectly drinkable. Wow! I have a feeling this doesn’t take to being bottled too well though.

Sampled from 22-oz bomber during Surly D-Day. Pours an opaque dark brown brew with a thin beige head that quickly disappears. Aroma of toasted dark malt, milk chocolate, a touch of lactose, and some powdered sugar. Taste is smooth, full bodied, with flavors of toasted dark malt, chocolate, a touch of coffee and lactose. Finish is smooth from its low carbonation with a dark malt and sweet lactose aftertaste.
GABF 2008. Black and oily pour. Liquid velvet bursting with rich roast, milk chocolate, with a creamy lactic sweetness in the finish. Outstanding.
