text: Poured from bomber...straight black with little ring of a head.  Aroma is somewhat subdued, but is inviting...milk chocolate, a hint of sweet coffee, and sweet malts.  Flavor is heavy on the milk chocolate, a good dose of lightly roasted coffee, and a heavy lactic presence...very good and extremely easy to drink.  More roasted flavors come out in the finish, but it is a very smooth end.  Good offering from FFF.

Bottle from StFun, thanks dude!  Poured a deep brown color with a thin beige head that quickly faded to a ring.  Aroma of dark chocolate, light coffee, lacto, and some oat.  Smooth, lightly sweet entry leads into some chocolate malt and a bit of smooth oat with a moderate lacto/milk character.  Finishes lightly hoppy.  Low carbonation, smooth but a bit thin on the palate.  This was very easy drinking, it just seemed a bit boring, and at the price, it isn’t a logical daily drinker.  Thanks Josh.

Tasting at mcbackus 10/19.  Finally I get to try this one.  Black pour, very small tan head.  Lactic smell with some milk chcolate notes, and roasted malt. Flavor is very nice.  Chocolate, roasty, and smooth.  I liked it very much. Another good FFF beer.

Bottle thanks to GMCC2181. Thanks! Poured black in color with not much head. Aroma was sweet, roasted malts, with a little but of sour milk smell? Taste was chocolate, a little bit of milk and malt. Finished ok, but not very impressed overall.
pretty black, just a thin head of tan suds.  roasty, milky nose... lactic roasty flavors...chocolate and lactic..smooth....cell phone battery about to die.

Bottle from, StFun. A little dissapointed in this beer. I just had a sweet "milk" stout from Iron Hill and this wasnt half as good as that... It was dark in color, not much head. Aroma of some sweetness. Taste was like a typical stout. A small amount of chocolate, hint of milk, roasted malt. Texture was average and to be honest the beer was below average for its catagory. I wouldnt consider this a sweet stout. Thanks josh for the beer!

Draught at GABF 2008.
Black coloured with a small beige head.
Light roasted aroma of chocolate and lactose.
Light roasted flavour of chocolate and lactose.
Roasted finish.

Dark colored black beer with a small tan head.  Nose of chocolate, roast, sugar and mocha, complex.  As with almost all 3 Floyds beers, they nailed it.  Was expecting a hoppy, out of balance beer, but it’s a complex, well balanced beer with lots of malt depth.  Creamy, with dessert-like malts.  Very nice ale.

22oz bottle from Travisd13. Pours dark brown with a thin light brown head. Smells mellow and sweet malty and milky. Tastes mellow roasty malty and sweet, some ripe dark fruits in there as well. Medium body, ok carbonation.

Poured pitch black with almost no head, chocolate and caramel in the nose, very mellow.  Roasted malt and chocolate taste, finishes kind of creamy, nice mouthfell.  Very little carbonation.  Flavor is very enjoyable, very mellow but tasty stout

dark pour - nice aroma sweet milk chocolate aroma- very smooth.  I really enjoyed this.. as with all mocha/vanilla stouts I feel it is missing something for me.  I really like the flavor and will enjoy again.  I am still partial to the extra bite in the IRS brews.

22oz bomber bottle. Poured black in color with a medium sized tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is sweet with chocolate and some light coffee. Tastes mostly of sweet milk chocolate, cream, with some light coffee. This would be a fantastic stout to drink with a chocolate cake desert.  Very nice.

Pours dark, dark brown out of the bottle and settles in pitch black under a small tan head that doesn’t hand around very long and leaves only a hint of lacing.

Smell is a combination of malted milk balls and coffee. Milk chocolate sweetness is present from the outset with a good roasted malt character as well.

The sweetness really takes over in the taste with huge milk chocolate and lactose sugars dominating throughout. There is a bit of roasted malt backbone before a slight bitterness that lingers through the finish, probably from the hops.

Mouthfeel is silky smooth and creamy with low carbonation. Creates a dessert-like sweetness on the palate.

This is a great sweet stout from 3F but getting through the whole bottle really takes some effort due to the huge heavy sweetness. Still, very tasty.

Nice black pour with a small amount of cream colored head.  Strong aromas of coffee, bakers chocolate.  Good roasted flavors of the same, along with roasted malts.  Pleasant, somewhat creamy mouthfeel, but could be more full bodied.  Finishes with a faint lingering sweetness, but clean.  If their intention was to create a drinkable summer stout, Id say they accomplished that.  I think this is a pretty good sweet stout, but not as good as the Bells or Rogue offerings.  I think 3F might be given a bit too much credit in its other brews based on the reputation of the Dark Lord.  The 2 Ive had of theirs(neither Dark Lord) have been a bit of a let down based on the hype for the brewer.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: I’m afraid imperial stouts have spoiled me, because after drinking them regularly for years, other stouts seem weak and thin by comparison.  It’s not fair, really.  This beer is, by far, superior to so many others.  Yet, compared to the potency of imperials, it seems almost meek in comparison.  I often avoid sweet and dry stouts, knowing my own tendencies, but an offering from FFF isn’t something to be taken lightly, so this was an easy buy.  It all starts off well enough, with that almost black color and dark brown head that I adore, though the head doesn’t last long enough for top marks.  Nose tends to be dominated by the chocolate notes, but there’s a definitive roasty quality, as well.  Flavor is well balanced between roast, chocolate, and coffee flavors, with lingering alcohol notes as it warms.  Mouthfeel is medium, with some creamy and oily characteristics.  As far as the style goes, this is quite good.  Hell, as far as BEER goes, this is quite good.  But it makes me yearn for the powerful grip of an imperial even more.

Pours a very dark brown in color iwth a bit of a brown head.  Smell is roasty, with some coffee notes.  There is a really good roasted coffee and chocolate flavor in the mouth.  This is unlike any other sweet/milk stout I’ve ever had.  I’m not usually into sweet/milk stouts, but this one is great.  Very creamy and full on the mouthfeel.  This is a very good beer, and it isn’t overhopped in the typical FFF way.  Very well done FFF, very well done.

draft at the maproom.... close to black pour with a thin clingy tan head.... aromas of sweet roasted malt, cocoa, and chocolate.  wasn;t expecting anything too complex with this one... very roasty and nutty flavors with an abundance of chocolate.  sweet and full flavored.  points for having a creamy and velvety mouthfeel.  started off pretty nice but the sweetness eventually took over in the end.

Black with a brown head.  Aroma is rich milk chocolate with roasty malts and tobacco juice. Medium body. Decent flavor is a little thin with chocolate truffels and some blackened malt bitterness to finish. Flavor was a bit of a letdown after the great aroma.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Poured from a 650 ml bottle.  Pour was thick, and had an impenetrable black void of a body, topped by a rich head of light brown foam.  Aroma is heady, sweet and has notes of chocolate and coffee.  The flavor is sweet and body is light (not wholly surprising) Palate is rich with notes of chocolate, mocha, with a slight alcohol burn.  Another nice offering from 3Fs.

Bomber courtesy of Bobby91w.  Pours a motor oil black with one finger tan head that receded quickly. Nose is chocolate milk, vanilla, hints of coffee and roasted malt.  Taste is pretty much the same.  Thinner mouth feel than I expected.  Decent brew.  Thanks Bobby!

Nice toasty molasses aroma.  Pitch black, motor oil like look with a gorgeous, large dark brown head.  Looks beautiful in a glass.  Flavor is sweet yet balanced, and actually less strong than what I was anticipating from the look of the beer.  The body is a bit lighter as well.  To me, the beer seems a bit deceiving in that it looks like it’s going to be thicker and darker than it actually tastes and feels.

Pours black with rich dark tan head. Aroma is roasted malt and milk chocolate. Flavor mostly roasted malts with tons of chocolate. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy.  A delicious stout that I could drink all night. They should put this stuff in 6 packs.

Pours a deep black with a nice soft tan head. Aroma is malty and milk chocolatey sweet and rich. Very nice roasted malt notes. Flavor is also sweet. The roasted malts really come alive and there is a nice bitterness in the finish that keeps it from becoming too sweet. Medium body and low carbonation. Really easy to sip on and a nice refreshing dose of malts.

22 oz. bottle from Binny’s (Orland Park, IL) shared with a friend. Poured the darkest hue I have ever seen, allowing no light through, an opaque black that didn’t even show light when held directly up to light. Aromas are coffee and some dark chocolate, usual for the style. Initial is a little roasted up front, moving into the coffee well and then finishing up with a touch of the chocolate in the finish and aftertaste. Smooth, very drinkable, but a little thinner than I expected. Not FFF’s typical "Hop and Hope" mantra, but still pretty good.

Courtesy of monsone.
Pours black with brownihs head.
Aroma of chocolat malts, some roastiness and coffee.
Taste lactose, extremelly sweet, coffee roastiness, with light notes of hops in aftertaste.
Another beer goodness to come out of 3Floyds. These guys are amazing.

Bottle courtesy of sebletitje. Thanks Sea Bass. Pours black with a one finger tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma is full on coffee, sweet lactose, dark chocolate, and roasted malt. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium full mouthfeel with a moderate amount of bitterness. A damn fine brew

Courtesy of Sea Bass. Pours deep dark brown with more yet less dark brown on the edges along with a nice mocha head. The aroma is chocolate and mild lactose, some roastiness and a bit of burnt malts. The taste is much the same with full chocolate goodness, dark roastiness and some coffee. Theres a mild layer of lactose way in the back along with a decent load of malty sweetness that grows into the finish. After a few quaffs I start to pick up a faint hoppiness into the finish too.  Very tasty brew.

22oz bottle with an incredibly sweet label and name.  Pours a dark black with a beige thin head.  Lots of roast in the aroma with some milky sweetness.  The pop of roastiness hits the tongue first going to a creamy milky and chocolatey sweetness before ending on that sweet charred note.  Body is light but fine for the style.   I’m actually surprised this isn’t hopped up, but it probably wouldn’t be very tasty if it was.  Well done milk stout.

Bomber from the first batch offered in bottles (and with a high fill line to boot!).  Hard roast and sweet lactose tones, but dry chocolate horizons.  Pitch pour with a creamy light brown head.  Crisp and creamy start, gummy berry roast and dry cocoa with light sweetness and faint ending bitterness, much more balanced than expected.  "Baltic" notes, as advertised, are showing in that nice berriness.  Smarties dust!  7% alcohol is not to be found, perhaps 5%.  Light body, creamy not watery.  Moderately interesting and well above average for style.  For once, a FFF offering without a snowplow hop profile, I like!!
On tap at the brewery. This dark brown ale poured with a decent tan head. There is a very creamy chocolate flavor with almost no hoppiness. Goes quite well with chocolate cake.
Pours black with a moderate brown head. Aroma is coffee like and chocolatey. Flavor is almost winey with a strong chocolate with very little carbonation. Very oily mouth feel. Very good.

22 oz. bottle.  Pours a deep black with a moderate brown head.  Aroma is slightly sweet with chocolate and toasted malts.  Flavor is nicely sweet, but not overpowering, with a toasty finish.  Palate is much lighter than I expected.  More of a drinking beer than a sipping beer, which is very nice, but quite different from what I expected.
0.65l - Nose is heavenly, chocolate and roasted coffee flavors.  Tiny thin head over black, black liquid.  Palate was like flat cola, a little sweet and flavorful. Nice

Pours a dark brown with a thin tan head.  Solid aroma of chocolate.  Great balance from FFF, a not a lot of hops.  Great creamy, smooth flavor, lots of good chocolate and coffee flavor.  I hope I can get this all year around, enjoyable stout.

Pours a thicker black with a nice creamy frothy tan/gray head.    Great aroma of cocoa powder, butter, a little roast and a nice amount of hops.   First taste is very milky and buttery, oatmeal?  Wow that’s awesome... so flavorful and drinkable.   A great stout that doesn’t allow the roast, coffee or dark chocolate flavors to completely dominate... imagine that.   The sweet creamy milkiness is forefront and the roast and chocolate play assisting roles, fantastic balance from FFF.  Perfect body, creamy and full, yet not heavy with just the right amount of light sizzling carbonation.   soooooo buttery!

Bomber! Dark stout blackish brown with thin brown foamy head. Smell was good, a bit on the sweet side. Taste is average with a bit of a hoppy ending and a heavy and dry mouthfeel. Expected a better flavor from FFF, this was not over the top for a stout.

This was a favorite of mine and i was glad to see it back in 22oz bottles,I had on tap at brewpub and this was a very sweet and smooth stout almost like guinness but with a lot more of a kick to it  very good and silky.CHEERS!

ultra black and non existant head.  aroma is of subtle sweetness immediately tempered with wonderful bitterness.  a nice mouthfeel is expected from any kind of porter or stout, but this is the defintion of silk.  it meets every curvature and crevice of your mouth and tounge and the bitterness lingers after its gone.  definatley not a dry end, but a plesant one.  this is a great style for FFF because its one that really benefits from the overhopping they are known for.  like their black sun, you find the best examples of balance in FFF beers when they tamper with the roasted malts.  the lactose pushes this over the edge, beating out in my mind alot of their other similar offerings.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2009 22oz bottle. The last time I had this was the first day the FFF brewpub opened and I recalled liking it a lot. I just missed this on cask at the maproom so I thought Id pay the ridiculous amount of $8 for a milk stout.  I came home and had the place to myself a bit and thought itd been a while since Ive seen "A Clockwork Orange" and this was the geekiest time as ever. So I opened this bottled labeled "Moloko Milk Stout" with probably my favorite FFF label to get me sharp and ready for the old ultra-violence. This poured rather heavy, black with tan head that didnt last long yet eventually formed again nicely. I thought it was a bit strange that no one at the Kovoko milk bar was drinking anything this dark but maybe this was a new brand or something, it smelled of lactose, chocolate, roast, and vanilla. tasted like sweet chocolate, lactose, mild roast, caramel, with a semi-sweet finish. a pretty heavy body with silky mouth feel. even though i felt a triple IPA would have worked a bit better with the film but hell i cant complain this was Moloko milk (stout)! 3.6. 

8/29/09, a full pour at the brewpub listed at 8%abv. this was very slick and sweet, cloyingly slick and sweet. really not very good at all unless you like slick and sweet. 3.2.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2012 Draft at Jerrys. Black with good, foamy brown head / Rich, sweet nose of roast coffee, chocolate, molasses, & licorice / Medium body, acidic with lots of bitterness, inky and sweet, with lots of bitterness on the finish  / Flavors of dark roast coffee and bittersweet chocolate, with notes of prune and caramel / A solid stout with a sweet and inky character.

I am not sure if i understand the mild stout appeal.  It was thinner than i expected, and the bubbles on top looked a little weird.  Kind of like milk in fact.  Too sweet for my taste.  Very dairy-y if that can even be said.  Might work as a stout float situation with ice cream, but other than that i dont have much use for this.  Pains me to say that about my favorite brewery.

Pours black with a brown head that dissapears rather quickly. Aroma is is malts, chocolate, and dairy creamer. Taste is all the flavors of the aroma with a very creamy mouthfeel. The more you drink of it, the more of a roasted coffee flavor, with moderate bitterness lingers on.

Poured very dark with little head and virtually no lacing.  Very little carbonation and hit fairly thin moutfhfeel for a stout.  Pretty sweet but overall unintersting to me.  With so many good things on tap at 3F, I moved on quickly.

Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of chocolate, vanilla, coffee, cream. A bit of a sharp coffee flavor that melds into a sweet chocolate milk flavor. Creamy mouthfeel. Really awesome, this is one of my favorite beers.

This was similar in ways to Guinness but done 1000 times better.  This was on tap at the brewpub and poured a nice deep, dark brown, almost black with a thick brown head.  The head dissipated after a little bit unforunately.  Aroma was of vanilla, mocha, chocolate, malts and some coffee even tho it wasn’t brewed with coffee.  Flavor was awesome at first but as I got towards the bottom, I kind of got annoyed with it.  The flavors were the same as the aroma.  Palate was creamy and thick and smooth, but same as the flavor, towards the bottom, it got annoying in some way, it was strange.

On tap at FFF.  Poured black with a creamy tan head.  Aroma was absolutely killer vanilla and mocha.  Taste was reminiscent of a latte, and had a sweet, but not cloying finish.  The only knock against the beer was that the texture wasn’t as creamy as one would hope.  Still, incredibly tasty and drinkable.

One of the best milk stouts I’ve ever had. Pours black, with a nice creamy head. Goes down very smooth....tastes of chocolate, vanilla and coffee. A very well balanced beer. The sweetest isn’t too overpowering either. They don’t have this stuff on tap very often, due to it’s seasonal nature....get it while you can!

On tap at the brewery:  Black in color with a brown head.  The nose was filled wtih milk chocolate, oatmeal and some coffee.  In the mouth it was creamy and inviting.  While not weighty there was nice concentration of flavor.

On tap at FFF brewpub.  Was a nice darkened black color with a nice creamy tan head.  It had great aromas of chocolate, roasted nuts, citrus, and slight coffee.  It tasted very smooth and creamy, full of roasted nut, bitter cocao, sweet chocolate, vanilla, and a little coffee.  It was balanced very nicely, and had a very round body to it.

On tap @ the Brew pub: Pours black with that classic nitro tan head. Mmm... When will this end. Aroma, chocolate, a little roasty, and some lactose. Flavor, chocolate, lactose, chocolate milk, a slight coffee hint to it, and some earthy notes on the finish. This would probably be much better without the nitro.

Black pour, somewhat lighter tan head. This was on nitro tap. (damn). Aroma is chocolate, coffee, roast, oats, caramel, a touch of hops. Creamy and smooth, but I would have much preferred it to not be on nitro. Really solid sweetstout that was put on nitro.

tap at the brewpub.  Pours a very nice looking dark brown/black with a creamy light brown head.  Good smell with chocolate and roasted malt, with a nice vanilla presence.  Flavor was similar with some milk sweetness.  Mouthfeel could have been more creamy, but overall solid for the style.

Draft (3F brewpub)  Pours a deep, dark brown with a smooth & solid tan head.  Aroma is dark roasted malts & coffee and a little semi-sweet chocolate.  Taste is wonderfully creamy & sweet, with the roasteds malts, some coffee and the chocolate spilling all over the tongue.  Wonderful brew.

On tap at the Three Floyds Brewpub, on the nitro-tap.  This stout poured a dark brown color with a thick, creamy tan head that lasted forever. Another excellent beer from Three Floyds!

On tap at the brewery a few years ago-- before the brewpub opened.  Im not a stout guy-- but this was just outstanding on tap.  Very sweet, but not cloying.  Ive never had a stout that went down so easily-- such a smooth, balanced beer.  Wish they had it on tap more often!
Drinking notes from GTM 06:  Wow this is can not be a stout.  I have never tasted a stout this sweet.  Very pleasant, must try again next year.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2006 2005 Growler from RooftopRogue shared with SuIIy and OldGrowth on 5/4/06 at approximately 8 months of age.I was certainly highly skeptical of the talk about 3 Floyds growlers being able to last about a year, but upon pouring this one, my skepticism went right out the window.  Wonderfully effervescent pour shows a rich layering effect with a large head that penetrates deep in to the glass and eventually settles out about two-fingers high.  Body is inky black-brown with a dark tan head.  Retention is medium-strong and there is light lacing left on the glass.  Head is dense and creamy.The aroma is rich, sweet and creamy.  Heavy, sweetened cream adorns the juicy drops of bakers chocolate, while plentiful lactic acid provides a balancing tartness/dryness.  Some minimal prunes and even a hint of some lighly charred malts make a showing, but are warded off by the milky/creamy sweetness.  The aroma is luxurious, rich, and strong, but so soft and comforting on the nose, with only the light lactic notes and easygoing roast adding any hard notes.The lactose and lactic acid noted in the nose pales in comparison to its appearance in the flavor.  A deep milk chocolate, with plenty of bitter black chocolate opens up initially, coating the palate, and is quickly subsumed by rich, milky cream notes that keep the palate wet and heavy, as dark fruits, brought on by roasted malts playing with the lactic notes, enliven things.  Some bare, graham cracker-like dryness asserts itself, briefly, and is then replaced by a crescendo of sugary, lactose sweetness on the finish.  Immensely creamy, chewy and rich on the finish.  Low carbonation allows the sweet, rich, milky flavors to shine, but cuts it just enough so as not to get cloying.  It is, certainly, very sweet, but the fantastic execution of the lactose addition is so well-done and, in my opinion, not overdone.  So many milk stouts purport this flavor and then it is barely noticeable amid the hops and roast.  I could see this being a bit too much when fresh, but after 8 months, it has evened out well.  No alcohol noted in aroma or flavor, nor is yeast apparent.  Hops have all but disappeared as well.
Tap @ brewpub.  Weak, weak, weak.  Too sweet and milky for my taste.  No coffee, toasted malt, or hoppy flavors here.  Like watered-down milk w/ a dose of sugar.

This draft brew from the brewery poured a medium sized head of fine to medium sized mostly lasting brown colored bubbles that left behind an unnoted lacing.  The body contained no visible carbonation, was opaque and dark brown in color.  Its aroma contained notes of dark chocolate malts roasted malts and nuts .  Its mouth feel is initially tingly with a lingering tingly  aftertaste.  Its flavor contained slightly acidic burnt malty sweet roasted dark malty notes and was very tasty.  An excellent beer that I would buy again.

Tap at 3F. Poured a small tan head that was mostly lasting, opaque, no visible carbonation, and a dark brown hue. Aroma was roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate and mimicked in the flavor. Smooth palate. Medium body. Nice brew!

On tap @ FFF.   Dark brown almost black body with a creamy tan colored head.   Wonderful  toasted coconut, chocolate, coffee aroma.    Creamy choclate, milky, coffee sweet flavor.   Big, thick, chewy body.   An excellent example of the style.   COuld drink this all day!

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2008 Re-rate: 10/10/8 - Ah, to try again three years after I first tried it. This one is from the bottle. Lives upu to and beyond my prior rate. Nose is milky with nice chocolate notes and smooth, minimal roasty bitterness in the nose. Taste is big and sweet, minimal roasted bitterness here either. I could drink this one all night. No tartness to be found and super smooth. Damn, this shit is classic. 8-4-9-5-17

11/20/5 - Deep brown with a creamy head. Definite roast with chocolate and coffee undertones. Quite sweet. One of my favorites that Ive had from them. Big body. Awesome. 7-4-9-4-15
black color, tan head.  aroma of chocolate and coffee.  creamy mouthfill.  interesting entry in three floyds stable.

Black with quickly dissipating head.  This stout is very rich, The flavor is big and assertive with chocolate, coffee, and cream, finish is not quite as long as most three floyds products rendering this chewy full bodied brew very smooth and drinkable though not as thirst quenching as their pale products.  Would make a great desert!

Black body, tan head.  Lactose and roast malt in the aroma with green viney hops. Not much sweetness.  The flavor brings in a medium-strength chocolate malt and lactose sweetness along with roast and the same hops.  A excellent sweet stout - sublime roast notes.

Sampled from a growler at the monthly meeting of the Champaign-Urbana beer club. This is my fourth experience with this beer, and each time I walk away less than impressed. Its a solid stout, but its fairly thin of palate and not very aromatic. There some milk and cream which is nice, its not over the top on the hops, but Im left wanting more complexity and, ultimately, more flavor. Whats there is some milk chocolate and some roastedness, but Im really pushing it to find much more. I like FFF, just not as blown away by this as others seems to be.
Semi-bitter flavor.  Dark color.  Smooth milky texture.  Caramel covered nut flavor.  Sort of a cold coffee taste but not overpowering.  Some sweet hints too.

Oh, Mama!  Thanks, Brian, for sharing this growler.  Stuff pours jet black like 10W40 with a thick and creamy brown head.  Decorates the glass with beautiful lace.  Stick your nose in there and smell butter toffee, hazelnuts, chocolate, cherries, roasted coffee, hops (it is 3F), and more.  Let the orchestra play their symphony on your olfactory senses.  Sip and feel the smoothness, the minimal carbonation, the creaminess.  The flavor blends everything to a basic of coffee with thick, rich cream and shots of chocolate and hazelnuts.  Yum.

jet black pour thick brown head nice lace.  Smells of some butter toffee sweet hints of milk chocolate and light bourbon.. mmm.. plaate is a bit small.  flavor is milk chocolate, the chocolate malt from the ice cream malts some light hop bitter.. dont know what kind some other roasted flavors and nice lactose.. Really really good stuff

Tap at brewpub. Very creamy and thick tan head. Dark stout body. Roasted chocolate "malt" and roasted sour milk and grain aroma. Thick, bourbon coated charcoaled wood taste. Some fruitiness in the background and also some slight hops in there. Pretty good... for me, a little too much roasty sour milk.

This beer boasts a dark black color (it must have been the lighting at Three Floyds Brewpub, but I think I saw a blue tint to this beer).  It is disappointing that such a brilliantly colored beer has a mere glaze of a head and leaves only a smidgen of lacing in its wake.   A nice hearty combination of coffee, chocolate, and toffee rise to meet the scent glands.  This moderately thick stout spreads evenly through the mouth offering a sweet coffee taste that has a hint of smoke lingering in the background.  The throat is not disappointed as the sweet coffee taste lingers and lingers and lingers.

Draught, new brewpub (November 2005):  Black. (Though at the end of the glass it became transparent and muddy golden-red brown.)  A gray-brown film forms after the foamy, big bubbled head fallslactic fruit and berry aroma with cherries, blueberries and sweet raisins.  While light coffee rests in the background, cherry alcohol and black raspberry bitterness clings to the palate.  Chlorophyll-coffee like flavours fill the finish with a lingering creamy dark chocolate.  Another unique take on a non-hop crazy styleI like these new experiments, though this one could have used a bit less of the sweetness and a bit more hop kick

On tap at the brewpub.  This is about as black as black can be.  Had a nice 1/2 inch rocky bubbly head.  A lot of roasts and molasses in the aroma and taste.  Nice and creamy going down.  Finishes a little sweet but a slight alcohol burn kicks in and balances it out.  This is a very nice stout, hell Im putting it on my ice cream.

Draft at 3F. Pours a drak black with foamy chocolate colored head. Nose is lots of chocolate, some coconut, and dry malt. Taste is like a milkshake. Lots of dark chocolate and some coffee, along with a nice caramel and coconut hint. Nice mouthfeel. Sweet, but not overly so. Getting a growler next time.

Draft @ brewery. Pours a dark black with a foamy brown head. Nose is deep chocolate and dry malt. taste is a milkshake, dark chocolate notes and more dry malt. Finishes with a creamy palate and slight dryness.
Drank this last night at T Floyds new Brew Pub.Black body with no light showing through. Chocolate, mocha...tad sweet aftertaste ...slick going down      Nice
Exceptionally creamy and delicious sweet stout, with pronounced coffee and chocolate flavors.  The palate is sumptuous, with a lingering aftertaste of mocha.   I drink these instead of dessert..

I think this was a surprise hit for a more experimental brew, but one with the greatest, never-get-the-rights-to-it name!!!!  Roasty and chocolatey with a drying acid bite at the finish. Awesome roasty, vanilla espresso aftertaste.  My boy, Ian drank most of the keg of this one!!!

On tap at the 2005 Great Taste of the Midwest:  Pours a rich robust opaque, with dark brown edges and a thin coating of tan head.  Aroma is dry, roasty and chocolatey with a touch of buttered popcorn.  Nicely balanced and lightly hoppy with plenty of sweet chocolatey malt and lactose.  An enjoyable stout that I hope they someday bottle.

GTM. Rich, stoutish aroma with some chocolate milk notes. Black body, fully opaque, huge light tan head. First impression is of coconut, but is more sweet milk. This brew was named after the "moloko milk" in A Clockwork Orange and quite honestly, this tastes like the sweet, alcoholic milk they referred to in the book. Outstanding. I wish theyd bottle this. Not much bite; smooth. Surprisingly high alcohol for the taste. Well done guys.

Thanks Duane for the hand bottled sample. Black body with no light showing through. The aroma is caramel, coffee, chocolate and a little hidden vanilla. Very smooth and inviting aroma. The taste has sugar sweetened coffee and smoot oatmeal. There is also some baking chocolate. The mouthfeel is slick. Nice version of a style I do not love.
Aroma was not very strong.  Chooclately with lactose.  Could taste some wood, chocolate and vanilla.  A very good beer.  Thanks to richlikebeer for sharing!

Thanks richlikebeer for sharing this damn nice brew.  Aroma was chocolate,coffee and a steamy milk.  Poured black with a cream head.  Taste was goood, chocolate and vanilla woody character with lactose to finish.  I found it to be very enjoyable that could easily turn in to two or three more.

handbottled bomber courtesy of Duane, poured a solid black with a thin cream colored lacing.  aromas of burnt coffee, chocolate, molasses and steamed milk, almost creating an expresso/cappucino smell.  amazingly smooth chocolate flavor, lactose at the end, burnt coffee and some sweet vanilla in the middle.  velvety smooth body, slides down your throat.  a little bit acetic tail, but this could be a result of the heat during transport...either way, a very nice sweet stout.  thanks alot duane

Tap @ GTMW.  Moderate viscosity and midnight brown in color with a few streaks of tan for the head.  Toned down aroma, with some rich chocolate, caramel currents in fudge brownies and dark chocolate fudge.  Flavor begins with a lovely creamy milk chocolate persona that Id have any day of the week to stow away in a milk carton and drink with my lunch.  Rich chocolate morsels, like spooning out the cookie batter and putting more in your mouth than on the cookie sheet.  Some brown sugar and maple oatmea.  Medium bodied.  This flavor is bitching.  A delectable stout.

This beers got a great aroma and appearance.  Black with grey head.  The first few sips are nice and sweet.  Then it just tastes really chalky and its quite unappealing.  The mouth fell is a little grainy like there are some bits in it.

On tap at the brewery.  Milk chocolate and espresso aroma.  Pitch black with fine brown head.  Tastes like a chocolate malt.  Very full bodied and sticky.    Reminds me of a Irish Car Bomb.  If you are not familiar, get a pint of stout, and drop a shot of Irish Cream in it, the chug.  The difference is that I didnt chug this, and it was much more enjoyable.

growler from the brewery.  this is one of those beers that needs to warm up a bit to really enjoy all of the flavors.  pours an inky, oily black with a ruby edge and a quickly fading tan head.  aromas of coffee, dark fruit ( prunes, raisins ) & milk sugar.  flavors of oatmeal, more dark fruit, coffee & cream without any bitterness or burnt edges.  nothing over the top, but a well done brew and worth the effort to obtain!

Rating #333... Im only half evil.
Black and oily with no head. Aromas were fairly weak, with only some roasted coffee and a hint of raisin. Moderately sweet in flavor to start with huge coffee bitterness coming through right after. More raisin and prune after that. Syrupy and oily to create a slick mouthfeel. Would pair well with Beethovens Ninth.

Tap, sampled out of a lovely plastic vessel alongside BBB63 during the great exodus.  Black colored with a quick fading head, somehow lacing is left decently.  Much coffee detected in aroma along with some sweet notes also.  Medium bodied.  Roasty, smooth, lactic sweetness remains in the shadows pleasantly.  Quite nicely done!

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2009 Draft at Floyds brewery. #8 of 31 US Beers for American Beer Month.  Whoa (again)! Very smooth and yes, very milky is my impression, like that chewing gum made with milk sugar thats supposed to be good for your teeth. Dark as coffee, and just a bit of a ring from the foam around the edge of the plastic cup at 3Floyds. Taste is of heavy cream and mocha, definitely with the smoothness of oatmeal at work, too (Nic confirms theres also oatmeal in this moloko, me droogies). Despite the preponderance of chocolate and coffee roast malts, theres not a rough note note to be found anywhere in this drink, until you notice the alcohol creeping up on you!

Pours inky black with a brown head. Aroma of burnt fruits, milk chocolate and milk. Flavor is rummy with chocolate and burnt fruits. Body is absolutely enormous, chewy and milky. No bitterness. Fairly unbalanced but enjoyable.

Big thanks to BBB63 for providing me with a hand bottled sample of this gem. Poured a dark brown color with a smaller sized off white head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, milky and I think Eric hit it dead on when he said marshmellows. Aromas where stronger than the tastes with tastes of chocolate, milky, roasted malts and a little nutty. Worthy of seeking out.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2009 Poured a dark brown, black color with a  creamy, light tan head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted coffee, vanilla, lactose, and marshmallows.  Taste of sweet chocolate, vanilla, and a dry, roasted malt finish.  Velvety soft mouthfeel.  Thanks BBB63 via hopdog!

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2005 Tap and enjoyed with a travelling Wolhfs: Opaque with a fading tan head and some lace. The aroma has notes of hazelnut, caramel and burnt malt, prune and berry, some lactic sourness, and a hint of piney hops. The nose gets better has it warms. The taste starts quite twangy with a hit of bitters. There is a nutty and roasted overtones followed by an ending of earthy yeast notes and coffee. The feel is biting and yet smooth, medium-bodied dry finish. This is a solid brew and beergeek worthy.

Poors a thick black with a quickly disappearing brown head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt and some smoke. Nice sweet roasted malt flavor with a chocolate milk aftertaste. Goes down smooth and better by the sip. can we call this Dark Lord Lite?
